BluePrints Pipeline Summary Here's how the app transforms FigJam diagrams into interactive flow charts: 1. FigJam Extraction (npm run extract:figma) Script: scripts/figma-extract.mjs Extracts raw data from a FigJam JSON export: Walks the document tree recursively Captures TEXT and STICKY nodes with their IDs, text, sections, and colors Outputs output/extracted/<fileKey>_extracted.json 2. Card Grammar Parsing (npm run flow:gen) Scripts: scripts/blueprints/generateFlowFromExtract.mjs + scripts/blueprints/parseCards.mjs Parses a DSL (Domain Specific Language) using prefix labels: PrefixPurposeG:Goal - Business/user objectivesP:Persona - User type definitionsA:Actor - Lane/swimlane declarationF: / FLOW:Flow Group - Named scenario/journeyS:Step - User actionSYS:System Step - Automatic system behaviorD:Decision - Yes/No branching pointE:Edge - Explicit connection (from → to)START:Entry pointEND:Successful completionEXIT:Early exit/error pathAC:Acceptance CriteriaQ:Open QuestionsRISK:Potential issues Output: FlowSpec JSON with structured arrays for personas, goals, steps, decisions, edges, etc. 3. FlowGraph Expansion - SpecKit Engine (npm run flow:expand) Scripts: scripts/blueprints/generateFlowGraph.mjs + scripts/blueprints/expandFlowGraph.mjs This is the intelligent inference layer that transforms FlowSpec into a complete FlowGraph: A. Lane Determination Collects declared actors (A: entries) Infers lanes from persona names Always includes System lane B. Entry/Exit Point Detection If explicit START: nodes exist → uses those Otherwise detects mode patterns (Solo/With Friends) and generates appropriate starts Creates END_SUCCESS, END_EXIT, and optionally END_ERROR nodes C. System Step Inference Pattern-matches content to automatically add system steps: { pattern: /permission|microphone|camera/, label: 'Request Permission' } { pattern: /lobby|room|session/, label: 'Create Session' } { pattern: /sync|synchronize|real-?time/, label: 'Sync State' } { pattern: /save|persist|store/, label: 'Save Data' } // etc.  D. Intelligent Edge Generation (The Core Algorithm) Principle: "Every node must be connected, forming a coherent flow" START → First Step: Connects each start node to first action in its lane Sequential Steps: Steps within same lane connect in document order Decision Branching (semantic-aware): Analyzes decision text to classify type (permission, availability, validity, readiness) Yes branch: Routes to next logical step No branch: Uses intelligent matching to find appropriate exit: Permission denied → finds "listen-only" or limited mode Unavailable → finds error/unavailable exit Final Step → End: Unconnected steps route to appropriate end node Cycle Prevention: DFS ensures no backwards edges E. Explicit vs. Inferred If E: edges are defined → uses those + fills minimal gaps If no edges → auto-generates all edges intelligently Marks inferred nodes with inferred: true flag 4. Web Rendering (FlowViewer.tsx) Uses React Flow to display the FlowGraph: BFS Layout: Computes node "levels" from start nodes, positions left-to-right Row Wrapping: Wraps to new rows every 4 levels Swimlanes: Color-coded by actor (User, Host, Guest, System) Custom Nodes: Different shapes for steps, decisions, start/end Interactive: Pan, zoom, MiniMap, edit nodes/edges Data Flow Diagram FigJam (Visual)  │ Export JSON  ▼ ┌─────────────────────┐ │ figma-extract.mjs │ → _extracted.json (raw text nodes) └─────────┬───────────┘  │ Parse DSL (G:, S:, D:, etc.)  ▼ ┌─────────────────────┐ │ parseCards.mjs │ → flowspec.json (structured data) └─────────┬───────────┘  │ SpecKit Expansion  ▼ ┌─────────────────────┐ │ expandFlowGraph.mjs │ → flowgraph.json (complete graph) │ • Infer lanes │ │ • Infer start/end │ │ • Infer system steps│ │ • Generate edges │ └─────────┬───────────┘  │  ▼ ┌─────────────────────┐ │ FlowViewer.tsx │ → Interactive Diagram │ (React Flow) │ └─────────────────────┘  Key Innovation: SpecKit The power of BluePrints is that designers can write high-level sticky notes in FigJam like: S: User taps "Karaoke" D: Is karaoke available? END: Session started EXIT: Karaoke unavailable  And SpecKit automatically infers: A START node connects to the first step The decision's Yes branch goes to session start The decision's No branch goes to the unavailable exit (semantic matching) System steps for data fetching are added if needed This lets designers focus on the story while the system handles technical flow details.
children.characters:
BluePrints Pipeline Summary

Here's how the app transforms FigJam diagrams into interactive flow charts:

1. FigJam Extraction (npm run extract:figma)

Script: scripts/figma-extract.mjs
Extracts raw data from a FigJam JSON export:
Walks the document tree recursively
Captures TEXT and STICKY nodes with their IDs, text, sections, and colors
Outputs output/extracted/<fileKey>_extracted.json

2. Card Grammar Parsing (npm run flow:gen)
Scripts: scripts/blueprints/generateFlowFromExtract.mjs + scripts/blueprints/parseCards.mjs
Parses a DSL (Domain Specific Language) using prefix labels:
PrefixPurposeG:Goal - Business/user objectivesP:Persona - User type definitionsA:Actor - Lane/swimlane declarationF: / FLOW:Flow Group - Named scenario/journeyS:Step - User actionSYS:System Step - Automatic system behaviorD:Decision - Yes/No branching pointE:Edge - Explicit connection (from → to)START:Entry pointEND:Successful completionEXIT:Early exit/error pathAC:Acceptance CriteriaQ:Open QuestionsRISK:Potential issues
Output: FlowSpec JSON with structured arrays for personas, goals, steps, decisions, edges, etc.

3. FlowGraph Expansion - SpecKit Engine (npm run flow:expand)

Scripts: scripts/blueprints/generateFlowGraph.mjs + scripts/blueprints/expandFlowGraph.mjs
This is the intelligent inference layer that transforms FlowSpec into a complete FlowGraph:
A. Lane Determination
Collects declared actors (A: entries)
Infers lanes from persona names
Always includes System lane
B. Entry/Exit Point Detection
If explicit START: nodes exist → uses those
Otherwise detects mode patterns (Solo/With Friends) and generates appropriate starts
Creates END_SUCCESS, END_EXIT, and optionally END_ERROR nodes
C. System Step Inference
Pattern-matches content to automatically add system steps:
{ pattern: /permission|microphone|camera/, label: 'Request Permission' } { pattern: /lobby|room|session/, label: 'Create Session' } { pattern: /sync|synchronize|real-?time/, label: 'Sync State' } { pattern: /save|persist|store/, label: 'Save Data' } // etc. 
D. Intelligent Edge Generation (The Core Algorithm)
Principle: "Every node must be connected, forming a coherent flow"
START → First Step: Connects each start node to first action in its lane
Sequential Steps: Steps within same lane connect in document order
Decision Branching (semantic-aware):
Analyzes decision text to classify type (permission, availability, validity, readiness)
Yes branch: Routes to next logical step
No branch: Uses intelligent matching to find appropriate exit:
Permission denied → finds "listen-only" or limited mode
Unavailable → finds error/unavailable exit
Final Step → End: Unconnected steps route to appropriate end node
Cycle Prevention: DFS ensures no backwards edges
E. Explicit vs. Inferred
If E: edges are defined → uses those + fills minimal gaps
If no edges → auto-generates all edges intelligently
Marks inferred nodes with inferred: true flag
4. Web Rendering (FlowViewer.tsx)
Uses React Flow to display the FlowGraph:
BFS Layout: Computes node "levels" from start nodes, positions left-to-right
Row Wrapping: Wraps to new rows every 4 levels
Swimlanes: Color-coded by actor (User, Host, Guest, System)
Custom Nodes: Different shapes for steps, decisions, start/end
Interactive: Pan, zoom, MiniMap, edit nodes/edges
Data Flow Diagram
FigJam (Visual)       │ Export JSON       ▼ ┌─────────────────────┐ │ figma-extract.mjs   │  → _extracted.json (raw text nodes) └─────────┬───────────┘           │ Parse DSL (G:, S:, D:, etc.)           ▼ ┌─────────────────────┐ │ parseCards.mjs      │  → flowspec.json (structured data) └─────────┬───────────┘           │ SpecKit Expansion           ▼ ┌─────────────────────┐ │ expandFlowGraph.mjs │  → flowgraph.json (complete graph) │ • Infer lanes       │ │ • Infer start/end   │ │ • Infer system steps│ │ • Generate edges    │ └─────────┬───────────┘           │           ▼ ┌─────────────────────┐ │ FlowViewer.tsx      │  → Interactive Diagram │ (React Flow)        │ └─────────────────────┘ 
Key Innovation: SpecKit
The power of BluePrints is that designers can write high-level sticky notes in FigJam like:
S: User taps "Karaoke" D: Is karaoke available? END: Session started EXIT: Karaoke unavailable 
And SpecKit automatically infers:
A START node connects to the first step
The decision's Yes branch goes to session start
The decision's No branch goes to the unavailable exit (semantic matching)
System steps for data fetching are added if needed
This lets designers focus on the story while the system handles technical flow details.

children.name: Generic Components (100% portable) 1. Extraction (figma-extract.mjs) Extracts TEXT/STICKY nodes from any FigJam file No project-specific code 2. Card Grammar Parsing (parseCards.mjs) Completely generic DSL parser Recognizes all prefixes: G:, S:, D:, F:, E:, START:, END:, EXIT:, etc. No domain-specific code Mostly Generic with Fallbacks 3. FlowGraph Expansion (expandFlowGraph.mjs) Has a few Spotify-specific fallback patterns that won't break other projects: CodePurposeFallback if not matched'karaoke' keyword (line 270, 357)Match "karaoke unavailable" exitsUses generic exit matching'solo' / 'with friends' (lines 529-531)Detect multi-mode entry pointsSingle START node'listener' persona (line 169)Map to User laneUses 'User' lane'host' / 'guest' keywordsSession-style swimlanesUses 'User' + 'System' lanes What Happens with Different Content If you change the FigJam content to another project (e.g., an e-commerce checkout flow): Extraction - Works identically Parsing - Works identically (as long as you use the DSL prefixes) Expansion: Won't detect "solo/friends" modes → creates single START node ✓ Won't match "karaoke" → uses generic exit matching ✓ Will use lanes you declare with A: or infer from P: personas ✓ System step inference still works (auth, save, load, validate, etc.) ✓ Recommendation The pipeline is project-agnostic by design. Just ensure your FigJam content uses the Card Grammar: G: Allow users to checkout their cart P: Shopper - wants to purchase items quickly F: Standard Checkout S: User reviews cart items S: User enters shipping address D: Is address valid? SYS: Validate address with API END: Order confirmed EXIT: Invalid address  The Spotify-specific code only provides enhanced intelligence for that domain - it won't cause errors for other projects.
children.characters:
Generic Components (100% portable)

1. Extraction (figma-extract.mjs)
Extracts TEXT/STICKY nodes from any FigJam file
No project-specific code
2. Card Grammar Parsing (parseCards.mjs)
Completely generic DSL parser
Recognizes all prefixes: G:, S:, D:, F:, E:, START:, END:, EXIT:, etc.
No domain-specific code
Mostly Generic with Fallbacks

3. FlowGraph Expansion (expandFlowGraph.mjs)

Has a few Spotify-specific fallback patterns that won't break other projects:
CodePurposeFallback if not matched'karaoke' keyword (line 270, 357)Match "karaoke unavailable" exitsUses generic exit matching'solo' / 'with friends' (lines 529-531)Detect multi-mode entry pointsSingle START node'listener' persona (line 169)Map to User laneUses 'User' lane'host' / 'guest' keywordsSession-style swimlanesUses 'User' + 'System' lanes

What Happens with Different Content
If you change the FigJam content to another project (e.g., an e-commerce checkout flow):

Extraction - Works identically
Parsing - Works identically (as long as you use the DSL prefixes)
Expansion:
Won't detect "solo/friends" modes → creates single START node ✓
Won't match "karaoke" → uses generic exit matching ✓
Will use lanes you declare with A: or infer from P: personas ✓
System step inference still works (auth, save, load, validate, etc.) ✓
Recommendation


The pipeline is project-agnostic by design. Just ensure your FigJam content uses the Card Grammar:

G: Allow users to checkout their cart P: Shopper - wants to purchase items quickly F: Standard Checkout S: User reviews cart items S: User enters shipping address D: Is address valid? SYS: Validate address with API END: Order confirmed EXIT: Invalid address 
The Spotify-specific code only provides enhanced intelligence for that domain - it won't cause errors for other projects.

SYS: - A system action ("SYS: Send verification email") A: - Actors/roles ("A: Host, Guest, System") F: - Flow name ("F: Login Flow") START: / END: / EXIT: - Flow boundaries Example Your FigJam notes: F: Login Flow A: User, System S: User enters credentials D: Valid credentials? S: User sees dashboard SYS: Log authentication event END: Success  SpecKit produces: A complete flow with START → steps → END Connections inferred (credentials → decision → dashboard) System action connected appropriately Yes/No branches from the decision Swimlanes for User and System Why "SpecKit"? children.characters:
What is SpecKit?
SpecKit is the "brain" of BluePrints - it's the transformation engine that converts your FigJam sticky notes into structured, interactive flow diagrams.
The Simple Explanation
Think of SpecKit like a translator:
You write sticky notes in FigJam using a simple labeling system (like S: for steps, D: for decisions)
SpecKit reads those labels and understands the structure of your user journey
SpecKit creates a complete flow diagram with all the connections, even filling in gaps you didn't explicitly define
What Problem Does It Solve?
When you design a user flow in FigJam, you're focused on the what - what steps users take, what decisions they make. But a proper flow diagram needs:
All the connections between steps
System actions that happen automatically
Start and end points for each flow
Multiple user roles (lanes/swimlanes)
SpecKit automatically infers all of this from your simple sticky notes.
How It Works (The Pipeline)
📝 FigJam Sticky Notes         ↓     Card Grammar (parsing your labels: S:, D:, G:, etc.)         ↓     FlowSpec (structured data about your flow)         ↓     SpecKit (expansion & inference)   ← THIS IS SPECKIT         ↓     FlowGraph (complete flow diagram)         ↓ 📊 Interactive React Flow Canvas 
What SpecKit Actually Does
InputSpecKit DoesOutputS: User clicks loginCreates a step nodeStep node with label and laneD: Is password correct?

Creates a decision diamondDecision node with Yes/No branches

No explicit connectionsInfers edges between sequential stepsAutomatic connectionsA: Host, GuestCreates swimlanesSeparate lanes for each actorMissing START nodeAuto-generates entry pointSTART → First step connectionMissing END nodeAuto-generates exit pointLast step → END connection
The Card Grammar (Your Input)
You write sticky notes with prefixes like:
S: - A user step ("S: User enters email")
D: - A decision point ("D: Is user logged in?")
SYS: - A system action ("SYS: Send verification email")
A: - Actors/roles ("A: Host, Guest, System")
F: - Flow name ("F: Login Flow")
START: / END: / EXIT: - Flow boundaries
Example
Your FigJam notes:
F: Login Flow A: User, System S: User enters credentials D: Valid credentials? S: User sees dashboard SYS: Log authentication event END: Success 
SpecKit produces:
A complete flow with START → steps → END
Connections inferred (credentials → decision → dashboard)
System action connected appropriately
Yes/No branches from the decision
Swimlanes for User and System
Why "SpecKit"?
The name comes from Specification Kit - it's the toolkit that generates complete specifications from minimal input. The output includes:
Specs - Technical flow specifications
Plans - Structured user journeys
Tasks - Implementation guidance
In short: SpecKit lets you sketch rough ideas in FigJam, and it builds the complete, structured flow diagram for you.

CONTEXT:
Project: Smart Watch Language Tutor  Client: Preply (conceptual)  OutputSlug: smartwatch_language_tutor  Version: v1  Date: 2026-01-26  Owner: Blue  Platform: Smart Watch (Apple Watch + Wear OS) + Companion Mobile App  Goal: Practice a foreign language with a live tutor through quick, on-the-go interactions  Constraints: Small screen, limited attention span, variable connectivity, hands-free usage
PERSONAS:
P: Traveler Learner — wants quick language help while navigating a foreign country
P: Busy Professional — wants short, focused practice sessions between meetings
P: Language Beginner — wants reassurance, corrections, and simple explanations
P: Advanced Learner — wants nuanced phrasing, pronunciation feedback, and cultural tips
P: Tutor — wants to deliver helpful micro-lessons without context switching
P: Privacy-Conscious User — wants control over audio recording and session history
GOALS:
G: Enable bite-sized live language practice sessions from a smart watch
G: Allow users to quickly ask a tutor a question or practice a phrase
G: Minimize time-to-connection with a tutor
G: Support hands-free and glanceable interactions
G: Allow seamless escalation from watch → phone when needed
G: Respect privacy, consent, and recording transparency
REQUIREMENTS:
R: App must support live audio sessions with a tutor
R: App must support ultra-short sessions (30s–5min)
R: App must allow users to ask a single question or practice a phrase
R: App must display minimal visual cues optimized for watch screens
R: App must support push-to-talk and hands-free modes
R: App must gracefully handle poor or intermittent connectivity
R: App must allow users to switch to phone for longer sessions
R: App must request microphone permission just-in-time with explanation
R: App must allow practice without recording by default
R: App must show tutor availability in near real-time
R: App must provide lightweight session summaries after completion
USER FLOW NOTES:
(3 Primary Flows)
FLOW 1: Quick Phrase Practice (On-the-Go)
F: Quick Phrase Practice A: User  S: User opens the language tutor app on smart watch S: User taps “Practice a Phrase” S: App prompts user to speak or select a phrase S: User speaks phrase they want to practice SYS: Match user with available tutor  D: Is a tutor available? E: D1 -> S5 [label=Yes] E: D1 -> END_EXIT [label=No]  S: Live audio session begins S: Tutor corrects pronunciation and provides feedback S: User repeats phrase  END: Session ends automatically after short duration EXIT: User cancels session early
FLOW 2: Ask a Contextual Question While Traveling
F: Ask a Question A: User  S: User opens app from watch complication S: User taps “Ask a Question” S: App prompts user to speak question S: User asks contextual question (e.g., ordering food)  SYS: Request microphone permission if not granted  D: Is microphone permission granted? E: D2 -> S6 [label=Yes] E: D2 -> END_EXIT [label=No]  SYS: Connect user to tutor S: Tutor responds with explanation + example S: Tutor offers optional follow-up  D: Does user want more help? E: D3 -> S9 [label=Yes] E: D3 -> END [label=No]  S: App suggests continuing on phone SYS: Hand off session to mobile app  END: Question resolved EXIT: Network interruption
FLOW 3: Scheduled Micro-Lesson with Tutor
F: Scheduled Micro-Lesson A: User  S: User receives watch notification for scheduled session S: User taps “Join Lesson” SYS: Connect to tutor session  D: Is connection stable? E: D4 -> S4 [label=Yes] E: D4 -> S5 [label=No]  S: Tutor leads short structured exercise S: User responds verbally SYS: Provide haptic or visual cues for turns  D: Is session exceeding watch-friendly duration? E: D5 -> S8 [label=Yes] E: D5 -> END [label=No]  S: App suggests switching to phone SYS: Transition session to mobile app  END: Lesson completed EXIT: User skips or postpones lesson
EDGE CASES:
E: User is in a noisy environment — offer text or repeat mode
E: Poor network — switch to delayed audio or fallback suggestions
E: Tutor disconnects — auto-retry or reassign
E: User receives phone call — pause and resume session
E: User denies microphone permission — allow read-only phrase review
E: User is driving — enable hands-free mode only
E: Time runs out mid-session — provide summary and follow-up
OPEN QUESTIONS:

Q: What is the max recommended session length on watch?
Q: Do we support text input at all on watch?
Q: How do we price or meter ultra-short tutor interactions?
Q: What happens if tutor availability is low?
Q: How much context should persist between sessions?

children.name: Spotify

BluePrints - Project Input CONTEXT: Project: Spotify Karaoke Client: Spotify OutputSlug: spotify_karaoke Version: v1 Date: 2026-01-26 Owner: Blue Platform: Mobile (iOS + Android) Goal: Sing along to songs solo or with friends Constraints: Privacy-first, low friction entry, works with imperfect network PERSONAS: P: Casual Listener — wants a fun, low-pressure way to sing along without needing talent P: Karaoke Host — wants to start a session fast and invite friends with minimal setup P: Friend Participant — wants to join instantly from an invite link and know what to do next P: Competitive Singer — wants scoring, stats, and bragging rights (optional mode) P: Social Sharer — wants clips/screenshots/results to share after the session P: Privacy-Conscious User — wants control over microphone use and recording, with clear consent GOALS: G: Let users sing along with synchronized lyrics for any supported song G: Support both Solo Karaoke and With Friends Karaoke G: Minimize time-to-first-lyric (fast entry from a song page) G: Make joining a friend session effortless via link G: Provide a delightful “session” feeling (lobby, ready states, shared experience) G: Keep the feature safe, respectful, and privacy-first REQUIREMENTS: R: Karaoke mode must display real-time synchronized lyrics with highlighting R: Karaoke mode must support Solo mode R: Karaoke mode must support With Friends mode (real-time session) R: Host can create a karaoke session from a song R: Host can invite friends using a shareable link R: Participant can join session from invite link R: Lobby must show who joined and who is ready R: Session must have a clear Start action controlled by the host R: Users can mute/unmute themselves during the session R: Users can leave session at any time without breaking the session R: App must request microphone permission only when needed and explain why R: Karaoke should be usable even if mic permission is denied (lyrics-only mode) R: App must handle network latency gracefully (allow slight desync + reconnection) R: App must show clear feedback for loading, syncing, and connection issues R: Competitive scoring mode is optional and can be enabled per session USER FLOW NOTES: (Steps) S: User opens a song detail page S: User taps a new action called “Karaoke” S: App shows Karaoke setup screen with mode selection (Solo / With Friends) S: If Solo, user starts immediately and sees lyrics sync with playback S: If With Friends, user becomes Host and a lobby is created S: Lobby shows session status and invite button S: Host sends invite link via share sheet S: Friend opens invite link and joins as Participant S: Participants see lobby with song + readiness state S: Host taps Start to begin karaoke session S: During session, lyrics highlight and users can mute/unmute or leave S: At end, users see a summary screen with share / replay / new song options EDGE CASES: E: User joins session late (mid-song) — should sync to current lyric position E: Microphone permission denied — user can still continue in lyrics-only mode E: Host disconnects — session should either pause, transfer host, or end gracefully E: Participant disconnects — they should be able to rejoin quickly E: Bad network causes lyric desync — show “resync” option and continue playback E: Song unavailable in region — Karaoke entry should explain and offer alternatives E: Invite link expired or invalid — show friendly recovery path E: Too many participants — enforce a session cap and communicate why E: User receives a call/audio interruption — resume experience smoothly E: Abusive participant — allow report + leave + block actions OPEN QUESTIONS: Q: Do we record audio at all, or is it a purely live sing-along experience? Q: Is With Friends playback truly synchronized or “best-effort” with tolerance? Q: Do we need a host at all times, or can sessions be hostless? Q: Do we support duets / rotating solo lines, or everyone sings everything? Q: Should sessions support video, or audio-only, or lyrics-only? Q: Do we support scoring in v1? If yes, what model and what feedback UI? Q: Where does Karaoke live in the Spotify IA (song page, now playing, search)? Q: How do we handle explicit lyrics / content controls in group sessions? Q: What is the max participant count for a good experience?

BluePrints - Project Input

CONTEXT:
Project: Spotify Karaoke
Client: Spotify
OutputSlug: spotify_karaoke
Version: v1
Date: 2026-01-26
Owner: Blue
Platform: Mobile (iOS + Android)
Goal: Sing along to songs solo or with friends
Constraints: Privacy-first, low friction entry, works with imperfect network

PERSONAS:

P: Casual Listener — wants a fun, low-pressure way to sing along without needing talent

P: Karaoke Host — wants to start a session fast and invite friends with minimal setup

P: Friend Participant — wants to join instantly from an invite link and know what to do next

P: Competitive Singer — wants scoring, stats, and bragging rights (optional mode)

P: Social Sharer — wants clips/screenshots/results to share after the session

P: Privacy-Conscious User — wants control over microphone use and recording, with clear consent

GOALS:

G: Let users sing along with synchronized lyrics for any supported song

G: Support both Solo Karaoke and With Friends Karaoke

G: Minimize time-to-first-lyric (fast entry from a song page)

G: Make joining a friend session effortless via link

G: Provide a delightful “session” feeling (lobby, ready states, shared experience)

G: Keep the feature safe, respectful, and privacy-first

REQUIREMENTS:

R: Karaoke mode must display real-time synchronized lyrics with highlighting

R: Karaoke mode must support Solo mode

R: Karaoke mode must support With Friends mode (real-time session)

R: Host can create a karaoke session from a song

R: Host can invite friends using a shareable link

R: Participant can join session from invite link

R: Lobby must show who joined and who is ready

R: Session must have a clear Start action controlled by the host

R: Users can mute/unmute themselves during the session

R: Users can leave session at any time without breaking the session

R: App must request microphone permission only when needed and explain why

R: Karaoke should be usable even if mic permission is denied (lyrics-only mode)

R: App must handle network latency gracefully (allow slight desync + reconnection)

R: App must show clear feedback for loading, syncing, and connection issues

R: Competitive scoring mode is optional and can be enabled per session

USER FLOW NOTES:
(Steps)

S: User opens a song detail page

S: User taps a new action called “Karaoke”

S: App shows Karaoke setup screen with mode selection (Solo / With Friends)

S: If Solo, user starts immediately and sees lyrics sync with playback

S: If With Friends, user becomes Host and a lobby is created

S: Lobby shows session status and invite button

S: Host sends invite link via share sheet

S: Friend opens invite link and joins as Participant

S: Participants see lobby with song + readiness state

S: Host taps Start to begin karaoke session

S: During session, lyrics highlight and users can mute/unmute or leave

S: At end, users see a summary screen with share / replay / new song options

EDGE CASES:

E: User joins session late (mid-song) — should sync to current lyric position

E: Microphone permission denied — user can still continue in lyrics-only mode

E: Host disconnects — session should either pause, transfer host, or end gracefully

E: Participant disconnects — they should be able to rejoin quickly

E: Bad network causes lyric desync — show “resync” option and continue playback

E: Song unavailable in region — Karaoke entry should explain and offer alternatives

E: Invite link expired or invalid — show friendly recovery path

E: Too many participants — enforce a session cap and communicate why

E: User receives a call/audio interruption — resume experience smoothly

E: Abusive participant — allow report + leave + block actions

OPEN QUESTIONS:

Q: Do we record audio at all, or is it a purely live sing-along experience?

Q: Is With Friends playback truly synchronized or “best-effort” with tolerance?

Q: Do we need a host at all times, or can sessions be hostless?

Q: Do we support duets / rotating solo lines, or everyone sings everything?

Q: Should sessions support video, or audio-only, or lyrics-only?

Q: Do we support scoring in v1? If yes, what model and what feedback UI?

Q: Where does Karaoke live in the Spotify IA (song page, now playing, search)?

Q: How do we handle explicit lyrics / content controls in group sessions?

Q: What is the max participant count for a good experience?
